reviewText: A family film well worth watching as a learning experience about the settling of America, and also as an emotional experience about the difficulty of keeping courage (and promises) when circumstances becoming really distressing-and-stressful.  Other reviews indicate that it is emotionally affecting both for children and adults.  I reacted to it variously with tears, and alternating feelings of tension and relief throughout.Many reviewers who've read the book say the book was much better because it gave a better sense of the relationship that developed between the young American boy and the Penobscot Indian boy.  The book also is said to give more detail about specific lessons for survival in the wilderness taught by the Indians.Without even having read the book, I felt a disappointment with the relationship between the two boys as depicted in the movie.  I think this was partly due to poor "acting" and partly due to the superficial treatment of the development of their relationship.  Both boy actors came across at times as "wooden".  I was chiefly aware that the only palpable feeling they ever radiated very distinctly was hostility.  (In fact, none of the Indians, even the grandfatherly one who looked like a sympathetic character, really expressed a clear and consistent friendship.  The motive behind the "grandfather"'s benign relationship with the American boy seemed to be just learning how to read and write so as to prevent any further tricking of the Indians out of their land.)  The two boys never came across to me as completely sympathetic characters, or sympathetic "PERSONS."  The  eventual feelings of friendship and brotherhood that they supposedly developed never felt palpable or real to me.  I "felt" them mainly as just two stilted boy actors.  In fact, except for the characters of the parents and Loomis, other acting in the movie seemed stilted or at an elementary level--but maybe that is an effect deliberately produced in movies for young people because they may best recognize meanings through more elementary acting.The roles of the parents were so realistically acted that several scenes in the movie seemed to me to be suitable only for adult audiences.  These were the two scenes where the parents argue hotly, expressing angry reactions to one another which seem to threaten the solidity of their love relationship.  I think that in real life such scenes are distressing for children to observe, and perhaps they would feel the same way in reaction to movie arguments between parent figures.  There is also a scene of reconciliation between the parents conveyed by the depiction of a long "smooch" in the presence of the young daughter.  These scenes, I feel, might "feel" emotionally embarrassing, distressful and/or "gross" for children and young people--but I could be wrong about this.Otherwise, for any adults or young people looking for a good family movie to watch, this would be a good choice, a good film experience.  Also, just for adults who prefer movies that don't immerse the viewer in graphic sex scenes, this is an interesting enough story.  It's a visually colorful movie, probably a bit too idyllic-looking in spots to be really true-to-life.

reviewText: This movie is in the tradition of "Old Yeller" and "The Red Pony" -- it's taken from a popular children's book, and it has been made into a very watchable film.  Journeyman actors such as Keith Carradine are very convincing  in a story about a family's life and survival in the wilderness.This makes a good movie for a family movie night, but I would then mix it up with something lighter to make for a nice contrast.  Two of my older children, teenaged girls, who were baby-sitting three younger cousins (2 boys and one girl under age ten), and my husband, myself and my dad all watched this together and we were all enthralled.  The three girls cried, and I was a little misty myself.  So I was glad to put in "Enchanted" afterwards, which we all loved, also. (see my reviewEnchanted (Widescreen Edition)
summary: Sad but very watchable family movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: Matt Hallowell is a 13 year old boy in the 1760's, left to guard the family land and cabin while his father makes a seven week journey to retrieve his mother and brother. On the first day at the cabin, the fast-talking, evil Loomis asks to spend the night, then steals the boy's expensive rifle while Matt is asleep. Awaking with a broom in his hands instead of the rifle, Matt pursues Loomis, but trips, rolls downhill, and falls unconscious into a creek face first! Matt is rescued by an elder warrior of the nearby Beaver tribe and is taken back to the cabin, where he is nursed to health. Although the Beaver tribe dislike the white settlers, a reluctant friendship grows among Matt, the elder warrior, and the warrior's grandson, who teach Matt how to survive in this inhospitable land. A fine tale of courage and historical accuracy, it's one you'll want to see.
summary: Historical tale of courage and coming of age.

reviewText: I have been a public school teacher and now I am a homeschooling mom.  I see so much out there for girls and so little for boys. I am so happy to see something that will leap in the hearts of boys.  I am not saying girls won't enjoy this, but I think it was made for boys just like American Girls was made for girls.  I admit, I have never read the book and if the movie and the book are as different as you say, we just won't read the book!  I got this movie because I wanted my child to see something of that time rather than just read about it.  I personally am a movie buff when it comes to historical fiction and other educational stuff.  I do believe in the value of books as well, but in this family we like to "see" it. I am not saying one is better than the other as far as a book vs movie, but we all have preferrences and ours just happens to be videos.It would be nice if the book and the movie were very close if not just a like.  We were going to read the book too, but after the reviews we won't.  I am glad we saw the movie.
summary: This is a total BOY movie and a great one!

"I liked the way we could go back to different sections, like when they were shooting arrows." "It showed a lot about hunting and building a cabin." "Matt got along with the Indians."  Best for ages 8 to 12.

reviewText: I love the story and usually the actors in it. I think this was miscast or maybe just the actors didn't have time to get into their roles since it seemed to lack cohesiveness and believability, compared to other roles Keith Carradine and Annette O'Toole have appeared in. The Native American tribe members, I thought, were awkward in their speech in attempt to sound authentic.I managed to finish watching the whole movie, which a shame to have to feel obliged to do, since the story was great. Younger kids may like it since they may not pick up on the fine points and see it as an adventure.
summary: Unfortunately fell short of my expectations..

reviewText: Wow, I've never seen anything like this, and I absolutely loved it!  Like the other reviewer on here, I hated to see the Indians leave and thought they could have at least stayed for the winter.  I thought, too, that it was strange that the family said nothing when Loomis took their belongings into the woods and dumped them all there.  I know they didn't see it happen, but they would have noticed that their things were gone, wouldn't they?  But other than that, this movie is outstanding and is one I will watch over and over, I'm sure.  I highly recommend it!
